title: 104_hr3335
content:
The Act titled "Federal Railroad Administration Performance, Personnel, and Enforcement Act of 1996" makes amendments to various sections of title 49, United States Code, including qualifications for the Administrator and consultation with the Federal Transit Administration. The Act "Federal Railroad Administration Performance, Personnel, and Enforcement Act of 1996" amends Section 103(c) of title 49, United States Code to require consultation with the Federal Transit Administration on commuter rail passenger service matters and establish oversight procedures. SEC. 5. FINAL AGENCY ACTION.

Amends section 103 of title 49, United States Code to make decisions of the Administrator in carrying out specified duties administratively final. Failure to comply with statutory deadlines for regulatory action is considered a final agency action for judicial review.

SEC. 6. STUDY OF RULEMAKING PROCESS. Before October 1, 1997, the Comptroller General must report to Congress on the rulemaking process of the Federal Railroad Administration, focusing on resource adequacy and improvements for timely regulations. SEC. 7 repeals Chapter 211 of title 49, United States Code, effective October 1, 1996. The provisions of sections 21101 through 21107 will continue as administrative regulations under the Secretary of Transportation. SEC. 8 introduces hours of service pilot projects. The Secretary of Transportation may approve pilot projects to demonstrate alternatives to strict application of chapter 211 regulations, including on-duty and off-duty periods. If less than 3 projects are underway by August 1, 1996, more projects must start by December 1, 1996. A report must be submitted to Congress by June 30, 1998. The Secretary of Transportation may approve pilot projects to demonstrate alternatives to regulations. A report must be submitted to Congress analyzing project effectiveness and recommending modifications to hours of service regulations. SEC. 9. TRAIN CONTROL SYSTEMS REPORTS. The Secretary of Transportation is required to submit reports to Congress on the evaluation and implementation of train control technology for commuter rail corridors and the national rail freight system by specific deadlines. The Secretary of Transportation is evaluating advanced train control systems for immediate use on freight railroads, outlining installation schedules, and assessing costs and benefits. SEC. 10. RAIL SAFETY PERFORMANCE-BASED STANDARDS. Amendment to Section 20103 of title 49, United States Code requires the Secretary to adopt performance-based standards for rail safety. The standards must achieve an equal or greater level of safety at a reasonable cost. The Secretary must report on progress by June 30, 1998. The Secretary is required to report on the savings achieved and projected in administering rail safety programs through September 30, 2002, as well as analyze the effects of performance-based standards on railroad safety and enforcement costs.
